newsitem.title: USA: Calif. utility stranded cost estimates contested.
newsitem.headline: Calif. utility stranded cost estimates contested.

text.p: A key California consumer advocacy group said Wednesday it will challenge the estimated cost of stranded investments the state's three biggest utilities face as a result of deregulating their industry.

The utilities - Edison International's Southern California Edison, Pacific Gas and Electric, and Enova Corp's San Diego Gas and Electric - assessed these uneconomic investments at around $28.5 billion.
Toward Utility Rate Normalization (TURN) said it will lead the fight to knock down those estimates.
The utilities filed Friday with the California Public Utilities Commission detailed breakdowns of these figures for 1998, the year the state plans to open its electricity market to free competition.

Edison, for instance, said bad investment writeoffs will total $3.3 billion in 1998 - $1.6 billion from mandated power purchase contracts, $1.1 billion from nuclear investments and $500,000 from fossil fuel generation plants.
Under a bill passed by the California Legislature over the weekend, the utilities are entitled to charge electricity consumers investments made under the existing regulatory system.
TURN said it remains concerned that the bill creates new restrictions which could discourage divestiture of power plants and increase the write-off costs borne by consumers.
The group also said the legislation, which is expected to be signed by the governor, overly restricts individual consumers and small business from joining together to bargain for lower rates.
